questions.text: A group of investigators is studying hemodynamic regulatory mechanisms in a human volunteer subject. The volunteer is administered a stimulant drug, and a sudden increase in blood pressure is observed. It is hypothesized that the increase in blood pressure causes stretching of the atria. Increased atrial stretch would most likely lead to which of the following changes?

choices.text: Increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions in the distal tubules and collecting ducts of the kidney, as well as reabsorption of sodium, are effects of aldosterone, not of ANP. Aldosterone is stimulated by RAAS, increased serum potassium, ACTH, the sympathetic nervous system, and decreased mean arterial pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitric oxide (NO) results in vasodilation and decreased platelet aggregation. NO is produced by vascular endothelial cells in response to a variety of triggers, including vascular injury and hypoxia. While ANP does cause vasodilation, it has no effect on platelet aggregation.

C) CORRECT:

Decreased reabsorption of sodium from the distal convoluted tubule and cortical collecting duct is one of the effects of ANP, which responds to increased atrial stretch (e.g., in hypertension or volume overload) by increasing natriuresis and diuresis in the body. In addition to decreasing sodium reabsorption, ANP increases sodium and water excretion by increasing the GFR via dilation of the afferent arteriole and constriction of the efferent arteriole. Lastly, ANP inhibits renin secretion and thereby RAAS. Together, these changes work to reduce blood volume, blood pressure, and cardiac output.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased reabsorption of solute-free water is an effect of vasopressin (ADH), not of ANP. ADH acts by increasing transcription and insertion of aquaporins into the renal collecting ducts. ADH is secreted if the body detects increased plasma osmolality or decreased arterial blood volume.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic vasoconstriction and stimulation of thirst, as well as sodium retention and increased water reabsorption, are stimulated by RAAS, not by ANP. RAAS is activated in response to decreased glomerular perfusion and by the renal sympathetic nervous system and is actually inhibited by ANP.
Image Description:

Flowchart summarizing the biochemical and physiological effects of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and current pharmacological inhibitors (overlay).
questions.hint: Atrial cardiomyocytes are stimulated by increased atrial stretch to produce atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP).

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of excessive bleeding after undergoing a dental procedure. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 195,000/mm3, a partial thromboplastin time of 44 sec, and a prothrombin time of 12 sec. A one-stage clotting assay shows a decreased factor VIII. Therapy with a drug that acts on endothelial cells is initiated. This drug is most likely to result in which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased cAMP in renal tubular cells
Increased tubular fluid osmolarity in the loop of Henle
Decreased binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptor
Increased permeability to urea in the collecting duct

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased cAMP in renal tubular cells would be observed in patients who were given vasopressin (receptor) antagonists, e.g., conivaptan. Desmopressin, however, increases cAMP via interaction with V2-receptors and subsequent activation of adenylyl cyclase. The effects of high cAMP concentrations include the integration of aquaporins into the plasma membrane of collecting duct cells and an increase in water reabsorption.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased tubular fluid osmolarity in the loop of Henle would be seen in patients who have received mannitol, which is freely filtered by the kidneys without undergoing reabsorption and thereby creates a strong osmotic gradient with subsequent diuresis. Mannitol is commonly used in patients with elevated intracranial pressure or acute prerenal failure. In contrast, the concentrating effect of desmopressin occurs only in the collecting ducts, thus leaving the osmolarity in the loop of Henle.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptors would be observed in a patient taking angiotensin receptor blockers, not desmopressin. ARBs would be of no use in this patient, as they promote diuresis through vasodilation and natriuresis and have no role in the treatment of hemophilia.

D) CORRECT:

Increased permeability to urea in the collecting duct is found in patients who are treated with vasopressin analogs. This group of drugs binds to V2-receptors, triggering a cascade of intracellular reactions that ultimately result in increased numbers of UT-A1 proteins in the apical plasma membrane. UT-A1 facilitates urea reabsorption in the inner medullary collecting duct.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased bleeding time would not be seen in this patient who is receiving desmopressin, which shortens aPTT and bleeding time. These blood parameter changes are mediated by a release of factor VIII and vWF through cAMP-mediated cell-signaling.
questions.hint: This boy's excessive bleeding after a dental procedure and an increased aPTT raise suspicion for hemophilia A, which is very likely considering his deficient factor VIII levels. Desmopressin, a synthetic analog of vasopressin, is the medical treatment of choice for mild hemophilia.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance. He feels well. His blood pressure is 155/60 mm Hg. Physical exam shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose concentration of 150 mg/dL and a hemoglobin A1c concentration of 9%. Treatment with lisinopril is initiated. Which of the following findings would be expected two days after initiating lisinopril therapy?



Glomerular filtration rate
Renal plasma flow
Filtration fraction



A
↑
no change
↑


B
↓
no change
↓


C
↓
↓
no change


D
↓
↑
↓


E
↓
↓
↑
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These measurements (GFR↑, RPF ↔, FF↑) can be seen in conditions that are associated with a decreased oncotic pressure in the glomerulus (e.g. nephrotic syndrome). A reduction in oncotic pressure causes less fluid to shift back into the capillary system from the glomerulus. Consequently, more fluid is filtered, increasing the glomerular filtration rate and filtration fraction.

B) INCORRECT:

This constellation (GFR↓, RPF ↔, FF↓) can be seen in conditions associated with: decreased coefficient of filtration (e.g., thickened glomerular basement membrane in diabetes mellitus or decreased surface area of glomeruli due to glomerular destruction in necrotizing forms of glomerulonephritis); increased hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's space (e.g. obstructive hydronephrosis); or increased oncotic pressure in the glomerulus (e.g. increased plasma protein concentration in multiple myeloma).

C) INCORRECT:

These changes (GFR↓, RPF↓, FF ↔) can be seen with administration of NSAIDs because they inhibit formation of prostaglandins, which act to preferentially dilate the afferent arteriole. Thus, NSAIDs facilitate afferent arteriolar constriction, increasing resistance to blood flow and ultimately decreasing renal plasma flow. Because the hydrostatic pressure downstream to the afferent arteriole is decreased, the glomerular filtration rate is reduced. These changes are equiproportional, so the filtration fraction is typically not changed.

D) CORRECT:

When initiating treatment with lisinopril, a modest reduction of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is typically seen within the first several days. Simultaneously, renal plasma flow (RPF) is increased and filtration fraction (FF) is decreased. The underlying mechanism is inhibition of angiotensin II synthesis, causing dilation of the efferent arteriole. This increases RPF and reduces GFR due to a decrease in glomerular filtration pressure. Also, the FF is decreased because GFR is decreased and RPF is increased (FF = GFR / RPF).

In patients with a preexisting reduction in RPF (e.g. heart failure), initiation of ACE inhibitors may lead to acute kidney injury.

E) INCORRECT:

These changes (GFR↓, RPF↓, FF↑) can be seen with mild or moderate hypovolemia. Decreased renal plasma flow is the inciting factor owing to renal hypoperfusion.
questions.hint: Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, which works by decreasing levels of angiotensin II. Angiotensin II normally constricts the efferent arteriole of the glomerulus.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after being found unconscious in her apartment by her neighbor. No medical history is currently available. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a glomerular filtration rate of 70 mL/min/1.73 m2 (N > 90) and an increased filtration fraction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis can cause an acute decrease in the glomerular filtration rate due to urinary tract obstruction following papillary necrosis. However, renal plasma flow is usually not affected by pyelonephritis. Therefore, the filtration fraction would be expected to decrease, not increase. Moreover, this patient is afebrile, which makes infection unlikely.

A decrease in renal blood flow and GFR can occur as a complication of severe urosepsis following pyelonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Obstructive uropathy due to nephrolithiasis would increase the hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule and thereby decrease the glomerular filtration. However, there would be no decrease in renal plasma flow. The filtration fraction would, therefore, be decreased, not increased

C) CORRECT:

Profuse diarrhea can quickly lead to severe dehydration and hypovolemia, which would present with hypotension, tachycardia, and possibly, loss of consciousness. Hypovolemia leads to decreased renal plasma flow (RPF), and subsequently, a reduction in glomerular filtration rate. However, hypovolemia also stimulates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which attempts to mitigate the decrease in GFR by constricting the efferent arteriole. Therefore, in hypovolemic patients, the percentage reduction in GFR is less than the percentage reduction in RPF. The net effect is an increase in the filtration fraction.

See “Changes in glomerular dynamics” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Salicylates (e.g., aspirin) are a type of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, which constrict the afferent arteriole, resulting in decreased renal plasma flow and glomerular filtration rate. However, filtration fraction typically remains unchanged. Moreover, this patient lacks other classical symptoms of salicylate toxicity such as tachypnea and fever.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple myeloma causes a pathologic increase in plasma protein concentration. These proteins increase the oncotic pressure of the serum and decrease the net filtration pressure in the glomerulus. The final result is a reduction in glomerular filtration rate and filtration fraction.
questions.hint: Filtration fraction (FF) is the ratio between glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and renal plasma flow (RPF): FF = GFR/RPF. An increased FF with a concurrently decreased GFR indicates an even greater decrease in RPF. Therefore, this patient is likely suffering from a condition that has decreased her RPF.

questions.text:
An investigator is studying physiologic renal responses to common medical conditions. She measures urine osmolalities in different parts of the nephron of a human subject in the emergency department. The following values are obtained:


Portion of nephron
Osmolality (mOsmol/kg)



Proximal convoluted tubule
300


Loop of Henle, descending limb
1200


Loop of Henle, ascending limb
250


Distal convoluted tubule
100


Collecting duct
1200



These values were most likely obtained from an individual with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In Gitelman syndrome, patients have impaired Na+/Cl- cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), resulting in decreased NaCl reabsorption and natriuresis. Because of the increased NaCl concentration in the nephron, the DCT should have concentrated ultrafiltrate. However, this patient has hypotonic urine in the DCT (100 mOsmol/kg).

B) CORRECT:

Volume depletion in dehydration leads to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) and increased ADH secretion. RAAS increases sodium and subsequent water reabsorption, thereby concentrating the urine. ADH secretion further increases water reabsorption and results in urine that is very concentrated, which is consistent with this patient's high urine osmolality (1200 mOsmol/kg) in the collecting duct.

C) INCORRECT:

In psychogenic polydipsia, patients have increased thirst leading to increased fluid intake. This increased intake results in dilute urine with low urine osmolality in the collecting duct (typically < 250 mOsmol/kg), which is inconsistent with this patient's concentrated urine (collecting duct osmolality of 1200 mOsmol/kg).

D) INCORRECT:

As a loop diuretic, furosemide inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle, which decreases salt concentration in the medulla and equalizes the gradient between the medulla and the cortex. Elimination of this gradient leads to decreased water reabsorption and ultimately causes dilute urine. This patient, however, has concentrated urine (collecting duct osmolality of 1200 mOsmol/kg).
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

E) INCORRECT:

In diabetes insipidus, the kidneys are unable to concentrate urine, thereby resulting in dilute urine with low urine osmolality. This patient has high urine osmolality in the collecting duct, which indicates very concentrated urine.
questions.hint: This patient's urine is hypertonic in the collecting duct, suggesting that the collecting duct is concentrating the urine by reabsorbing a disproportionately high volume of water due to an increase in ADH secretion.

questions.text:
A researcher is studying the effects of a new antihypertensive medication on urine osmolality. She first measures urine osmolality in different parts of the nephron of a healthy human control. The findings are shown below:


Portion of nephron
Urine osmolality (mOsmol/kg)



Proximal convoluted tubule
300


Loop of Henle, descending limb
1200


Loop of Henle, ascending limb
200


Distal convoluted tubule
100


Collecting duct
600



Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the urine osmolality in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased transcription of water channels, or aquaporins, results from elevated ADH secretion (physiologically secondary to volume depletion). Aquaporins, however, act at the collecting duct and not at the loop of Henle, meaning changes to them would not explain the differences between urine osmolality in the ascending and descending limbs.

B) INCORRECT:

The ascending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to sodium, which permits solutes to move down the concentration gradient and causes the urine to become more dilute in the ascending limb. Someone with impermeability to sodium in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle would have a similar osmolality in the ascending limb as in the descending limb, which is not the case in this healthy human control.

C) INCORRECT:

Urea reabsorption and secretion occur by passive diffusion. The thin loop of Henle is permeable to urea and because of certain concentration gradients, urea is usually secreted into the loop of Henle. However, because there is only passive and no active transport of urea, it is unlikely that increased urea secretion alone can explain the much lower urine osmolality seen in the ascending limb relative to the descending limb of the loop of Henle in this healthy human control.

D) INCORRECT:

Bicarbonate reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) through diffusion of carbon dioxide gas, which is formed when bicarbonate combines with hydrogen ions in the urine of the PCT. Bicarbonate reabsorption does not occur in the loop of Henle and would not explain the urine osmolality in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

E) CORRECT:

The ascending limb of the loop of Henle is impermeable to water but is permeable to solutes, which leads to decreased urine osmolality relative to the descending limb. Before entering the ascending limb, urine first travels through the descending limb of the loop of Henle. The descending loop is passively permeable to solutes and water, which causes urine to become more concentrated as it moves down the descending limb due to medullary hypertonicity. This hypertonic urine then moves on to the thin ascending loop of Henle, which is permeable to solutes but not permeable to water. Solutes move down the concentration gradient and are passively reabsorbed; as the urine moves on to the thick ascending limb, which remains impermeable to water, there is active reabsorption of solutes. As a result, the urine becomes more dilute, causing low urine osmolality in the ascending loop of Henle as seen in this healthy control.
questions.hint: The decreased urine osmolality in the ascending limb relative to the descending limb of the loop of Henle suggests that urine is less concentrated in the ascending limb.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of severe flank pain on the left side. He has no history of serious illness. He appears to be in distress. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with mild left-sided tenderness. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 12 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 0.9 mg/dL. The results of a complete blood count are within the reference ranges. A CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is shown. Which of the following changes are expected in the affected kidney of this patient?



Filtration fraction
Glomerular filtration rate



A
↑
↑


B
↑
↓


C
↓
↓


D
no change
↓


E
no change
no change
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

These changes can occur as a result of efferent arteriole constriction, renal vein obstruction, or a decrease in plasma protein concentration. Efferent arteriole constriction and renal vein obstruction increase glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, which increases GFR and reduces RPF, thereby increasing FF. A decrease in plasma protein concentration decreases glomerular capillary oncotic pressure, which increases GFR (but does not affect the RPF) and thereby increases FF. A different set of changes is expected in obstructive uropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

These changes can occur with dehydration or hypovolemia when there is a greater decrease in RPF than in GFR. Hypovolemia leads to prerenal kidney injury with a BUN:creatinine ratio > 20, whereas this patient presents with a BUN:creatinine ratio of 13.3. A different set of changes is expected in patients with obstructive uropathy.

C) CORRECT:

Obstructive uropathy limits the flow of urine from the affected kidney to the bladder. This backup of urine increases hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman space, which decreases fluid filtration from the glomerular capillary and decreases GFR. In obstructive uropathy, there may be a slight temporary increase in RPF resulting from prostaglandin release within the first few hours, followed by a slight decrease in RPF due to thromboxane A2 release. However, the decrease in GFR is much greater than the decrease in RPF, which is largely unaffected. Because GFR decreases with minimal change in RPF, the FF decreases. Despite the decrease of GFR in the affected kidney, patients do not develop azotemia if the other kidney remains functionally intact. If hydronephrosis due to obstructive uropathy resolves quickly (via stone removal or spontaneous stone passage), GFR in the affected kidney will normalize. If hydronephrosis is not corrected quickly, renal function may be irreversibly damaged because of ischemic tubular atrophy and thinning of the renal cortex and medulla.

See “Changes in glomerular dynamics” table.

D) INCORRECT:

These changes can occur with afferent arteriole constriction and renal artery stenosis when there is a decrease in GFR that is proportional to the decrease in RPF. This patient has obstructive uropathy, which causes a different set of changes.

E) INCORRECT:

Obstructive uropathy increases hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman space and changes the affected kidney's filtration process.
questions.hint: Unilateral flank pain in combination with imaging findings of hydronephrosis and a hyperdense calculus is consistent with obstructive uropathy due to nephrolithiasis. The filtration fraction (FF) is directly proportional to glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and inversely proportional to renal plasma flow (RPF) because FF = GFR/RPF.

questions.text: An investigator studying renal physiology uses para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) to estimate the renal plasma flow in a human volunteer. An intravenous infusion of 400 mg of PAH solution is administered to the subject; effective renal plasma flow is calculated to be 600 mL/min. Next, an intravenous infusion of 1000 mg of PAH solution is administered to the subject; effective renal plasma flow is calculated to be 400 mL/min. Which of the following explains the measured decline in the calculated effective renal plasma flow?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum protein binding can reduce the excretion of a substrate. As PAH does not bind to serum proteins, this is not a relevant factor in this case and would not explain the decrease in effective renal plasma flow calculated here.

B) INCORRECT:

Plasma oncotic pressure is dependent on plasma protein (e.g., albumin) concentration. Increased oncotic pressure does not affect the renal plasma flow and is therefore unlikely to be the mechanism behind the decrease in effective renal plasma flow calculated here. It would, however, cause a decrease in GFR, resulting in a decrease in filtration fraction (FF=GFR/RPF).

C) INCORRECT:

Efferent arteriolar dilation is a mechanism by which the kidney can regulate renal plasma flow and filtration fraction. Dilation of the efferent arterioles would result in increased renal plasma flow and is the mechanism behind ACE inhibitors (inhibition of angiotensin II → blocks efferent arteriole constriction). This mechanism would not explain the decrease in effective renal plasma flow calculated here.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the afferent arterioles (e.g., due to prostaglandins) would lead to an increase in renal plasma flow and increase in GFR. However, this mechanism would not explain the decrease in effective renal plasma flow calculated here.

E) CORRECT:

Clearance of para-aminohippuric acid depends both on filtration in Bowman's capsule and secretion into the proximal tubule by organic anion transporters on the basolateral membrane. If PAH plasma concentrations exceed the transport capacity of the organic anion transporters, not all plasma will be cleared of PAH. This results in decreased PAH clearance and underestimation of the renal plasma flow.

Effective renal plasma flow can be estimated from the clearance of PAH using this formula: eRPF = (urine concentration of PAH) x (urine flow rate/plasma concentration of PAH) = clearance of PAH
Image Description:

Clearance describes the assumed plasma volume that has been cleared by a substance within a certain period. It is a sensitive indicator for the assessment of kidney function.
questions.hint: Para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) is both filtered and secreted in the kidneys.

questions.text: A study of a new antihypertensive drug that affects glomerular filtration rate is being conducted. Infusion of drug X causes constriction of the efferent arteriole. After infusion of the drug, the following glomerular values are obtained from an experimental subject: hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillary (PGC) of 48 mm Hg, oncotic pressure of the glomerular capillary (πGC) of 23 mm Hg, hydrostatic pressure of Bowman’s space (PBS) of 10 mm Hg, and oncotic pressure of Bowman’s space (πBS) of 0 mm Hg. Which of the following best measures net filtration pressure in this participant?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's net glomerular filtration pressure is 15 mmHg. This net filtration pressure is calculated by subtracting the difference in oncotic pressure across the glomerular barrier from the difference in hydrostatic pressure across the barrier, such that: filtration pressure = (PGC - PBS) - (πGC - πBS). In this case, net filtration pressure is (48 – 10) – (23 - 0) = 15 mmHg. This patient's net filtration is increased (normal: 13 mmHg) because of the action of drug X, a result of increased glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure secondary to constriction of the efferent arteriole.

B) INCORRECT:

35 mmHg is obtained by incorrectly subtracting the oncotic pressure of the glomerular capillary from the hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillary (PGC - πGC) and adding the hydrostatic pressure of Bowman space (PBS): (48 - 23) + 10 = 35 mm Hg.

C) INCORRECT:

61 mmHg is obtained by summing the total pressure of the glomerular capillary (PGC + πGC) and subtracting the total pressure of the Bowman capsule (PBS + πBS): (48 + 23) - (10 + 0) = 61 mm Hg. As positive hydrostatic and oncotic pressures will draw fluid in opposite directions, this is not the correct way to measure the net filtration pressure across the barrier.

D) INCORRECT:

0 mm Hg is the normal oncotic pressure of the Bowman Space (BS), which is not a measure of filtration rate. The pressure of BS is typically 0 mm Hg because proteins are not typically filtered across the membrane into this space. However, in nephrotic syndrome, the presence of proteins leaking across the dysfunctional barrier increases the oncotic pressure above 0 mm Hg, favoring filtration and drawing more fluid into the BS. This is one of the reasons patients with nephrotic syndrome can present with increased GFR.

E) INCORRECT:

81 mmHg is the total sum of all the given pressures (PGC, PBS, πGC, and πBS). This is not an estimate of net filtration pressure, nor is it a useful measurement.
questions.hint: Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is driven by the difference between both hydrostatic and osmotic pressure across the glomerular filtration barrier.

questions.text: Two days after undergoing transsphenoidal removal of a pituitary macroadenoma, a 35-year-old woman reports increased thirst and frequent urination. The surgery was uncomplicated. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum sodium concentration is 153 mEq/L and fasting serum glucose concentration is 92 mg/dL. Which of the following findings in the nephron best describes the tubular osmolality, compared with serum, in this patient?

choices.text: Distal ascending loop of Henle is hypertonic
Distal descending loop of Henle is hypotonic

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sodium, potassium, and chloride are reabsorbed in the distal ascending loop of Henle, which is impermeable to water and hypotonic (∼100 mOsm/L) compared to the serum. The ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to water regardless of ADH concentrations. Therefore, this part of the nephron would remain physiologically hypotonic, not hypertonic, even in the setting of central DI.

B) INCORRECT:

Osmotic movement of water in the descending loop of Henle is driven by the hyperosmolality of the interstitial space of the renal medulla. The fluid in the distal part of the descending loop of Henle is, therefore, hypertonic (600-1200 mOsm/L) compared to the serum. This hypertonicity is not affected by ADH, as there are no V2 receptors located here.

C) INCORRECT:

In the proximal convoluted tubule, water and solutes (e.g., electrolytes) are reabsorbed in equal amounts. The osmolality of the tubular fluid in the PCT is dependent on serum osmolality, rather than ADH levels. The PCT would, therefore, remain isotonic (∼300 mOsm/L) rather than hypertonic when compared to the serum.

D) CORRECT:

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused by a lack of ADH, which impairs the reabsorption of free water from the collecting ducts (and the late distal convoluted tubules). ADH normally stimulates V2 receptors to increase the expression of aquaporins. The inability to reabsorb free water (e.g., inability to concentrate the urine) results in hypotonic urine, polyuria, and dehydration, which in turn triggers thirst and polydipsia, as seen in this patient. Urine osmolality is typically low (< 500 mOsmol/kg) and serum osmolality is high (> 299 mOsmol/kg) in patients with DI.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

E) INCORRECT:

Water and sodium chloride are reabsorbed in the distal convoluted tubule, which has V2 receptors that are stimulated by ADH. However, a lack of ADH would decrease the permeability to water and thereby decrease the osmolality in this part of the nephron, making the fluid in the distal convoluted tubule hypotonic, not hypertonic.
questions.hint: Polyuria, polydipsia, and mild hypernatremia should raise suspicion for inadequate ADH. The history of recent neurosurgery suggests central diabetes insipidus caused by damage to the hypothalamus or hypothalamic tract.

questions.text: An investigator is studying patients with acute decompensated congestive heart failure. He takes measurements of a hormone released from atrial myocytes, as well as serial measurements of left atrial and left ventricular pressures. The investigator observes a positive correlation between left atrial pressures and the serum level of this hormone. Which of the following is most likely the mechanism of action of this hormone?

choices.text: Decreases sodium reabsorption at the collecting tubules
Increases potassium excretion at the collecting ducts
Decreases reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubules
Increases free water reabsorption from the distal tubules

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ANP dilates the afferent arterioles and constricts the efferent arterioles, which increases glomerular filtration rate by increasing the net filtration pressure. Moreover, ANP decreases sodium reabsorption in the principal cells of the collecting tubule. Using these two mechanisms, ANP promotes natriuresis in response to increased stretch on the atrial lumen in an attempt to reduce the impact of volume overload. While atrial myocytes release ANP upon stretching, ventricular myocytes liberate BNP, which has a similar effect but lasts longer than ANP. Hence, BNP and NT-pro BNP levels are important serum markers for the diagnosis of CHF.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased potassium excretion at the collecting ducts occurs with hyperaldosteronism. Aldosterone increases extracellular fluid. In these patients, however, this mechanism would worsen cardiac congestion. In this patient, ANP is released, which decreases potassium excretion.

C) INCORRECT:

Constriction of afferent arterioles decreases renal blood flow and thereby reduces glomerular filtration rate (GFR), which then reduces urine output and worsens congestion in patients with CHF exacerbations. In contrast, the release of ANP in this patient attempts to compensate volume overload by stimulating afferent arteriole dilation and promoting natriuresis.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) leads to urine alkalinization and causes mild diuresis. Although this might moderately decrease congestion in patients with CHF, this does not describe the mechanism of action of the ANP released in this patient. It does, however, describe the MOA of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide).

E) INCORRECT:

Increased free water reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) is mediated by the antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which is released in response to decreased atrial pressure. This investigator observes serum concentration of ANP, which increases diuresis by inhibiting sodium reabsorption. ANP does not play a role in regulating free water reabsorption. Moreover, increased free water reabsorption would worsen congestion in patients with CHF exacerbations.
questions.hint: Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) is a hormone released from the atrial myocytes in response to increased stretch on the atrial lumen, especially in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) exacerbations.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effect of antihypertensive drugs on cardiac output and renal blood flow. For comparison, a healthy volunteer is given a placebo and a continuous infusion of para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) to achieve a plasma concentration of 0.02 mg/ml. His urinary flow rate is 1.5 ml/min and the urinary concentration of PAH is measured to be 8 mg/ml. His hematocrit is 50%. Which of the following values best estimates cardiac output in this volunteer?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calculating the cardiac output from the renal plasma flow (RPF) will underestimate the true CO. In this patient, the RPF is 600 mL/min, which would incorrectly lead to an estimated CO of 2.4–3.0 L/min (0.6 L/min/0.25 or 0.6/0.20 = 2.4 or 3.0 L/min, respectively). CO is correctly calculated using the renal blood flow (RBF), which itself is determined using RPF (RBF = RPF/(1 - Hct)).

B) CORRECT:

To calculate cardiac output, the renal plasma flow (RPF) and renal blood flow (RBF) will first need to be determined. RPF = (UPAH x Urine flow rate)/PPAH, where UPAH = urine concentration of para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) and PPAH = plasma concentration of PAH. Thus, RPF = 8 x 1.5/0.02 = 600 ml/min. Next, RBF = RPF/(1 - Hct); RBF = 600/(1 - 0.5) = 1.2 L/min. Finally, the kidneys receive 20–25% of cardiac output, so that this person's CO is 4.8–6.0 L/min (1.2 L/min/0.25 or 1.2/0.20 = 4.8 or 6.0 L/min, respectively).

C) INCORRECT:

A cardiac output of 8 L/min would provide the kidneys with 1.6–2.0 L/min (8 L/min x 0.20 or 0.25, respectively). This patient's renal blood flow is not within this range.

D) INCORRECT:

It is correct that this patient's renal blood flow (RBF) is 1.2 L/min. The RBF can now be used to calculate overall cardiac output because RBF is a relatively constant proportion of CO (20–25%).

E) INCORRECT:

Assuming that this number was determined with a correct renal blood flow (RBF) of 1.2 L/min, it was likely calculated assuming an RBF of 30% of the cardiac output (1.2 L/min/0.30 = 4 L/min). However, a healthy individual's RBF is ∼ 20–25% of the cardiac output (CO).
questions.hint: Renal blood flow in a healthy individual is ∼ 20–25% of the cardiac output (CO).

questions.text: An investigator is studying mechanisms of urea excretion in humans. During the experiment, a healthy male volunteer receives a continuous infusion of para-aminohippurate (PAH) to achieve a PAH plasma concentration of 0.01 mg/mL. A volume of 1.0 L of urine is collected over a period of 10 hours; the urine flow rate is 1.66 mL/min. The urinary concentration of PAH is measured to be 3.74 mg/mL and his serum concentration of urea is 0.2 mg/mL. Assuming a normal filtration fraction of 20%, which of the following best estimates the filtered load of urea in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Urea is freely filtered in the glomerulus and is also both secreted (via Loop of Henle) and reabsorbed (via proximal convoluted tubule, collecting duct) to a certain extent. However, the amount of secretion and reabsorption are irrelevant for calculating the filtered load, which refers only to the amount of the substance entering the glomerulus via filtration over time. Because urea is freely filtered, and not transported via larger proteins or lipophilic substances, the filtered load can be estimated via standard formulas:

eRPF = (UPAH x V)/PPAH= (3.74 mg/mL x 1.66 mL/min)/(0.01 mg/mL) = 620 mL/min

FF = GFR/eRPF ↔ GFR = FF x eRPF → GFR = (0.2) x (620 mL/min) = 124 mL/min

Filtered load of urea = GFR x urea plasma concentration = (124 mL/min) x (0.2 mg/mL) = 24.8 mg/min

B) INCORRECT:

The eRPF is 620 mL/min. This number is required to calculate GFR and eventually the filtered load of urea.

eRPF = (UPAH x V)/PPAH = (3.74 mg/mL x 1.66 mL/min)/(0.01 mg/mL) = 620 mL/min

C) INCORRECT:

The GFR is 124 mL/min. This number is required to calculate the filtered load of urea.

GFR = FF*eRPF = (0.2) x (620 mL/min) = 124 mL/min

D) INCORRECT:

This would be the filtered load of urea if an incorrect formula for eRPF was used by initially forgetting to factor in the urine PAH concentration. This would yield an abnormally low eRPF of around 166 mL/min and accordingly an abnormally low GFR (33 mL/min) and filtered load. Normal eRPF is around 600 mL/min, and normal GFR is around 120 mL/min for men.

Filtered load of urea = GFR x urea plasma concentration = (33.2 mL/min) x (0.2 mg/mL) = 6.6 mg/min

E) INCORRECT:

This number is part of the calculation of eRPF in this patient (V/PPAH) but is not a completed calculation. eRPF is needed to calculate the filtered load of urea.

eRPF = (UPAH x V)/PPAH = (3.74 mg/mL x 1.66 mL/min)/(0.01 mg/mL) = 620 mL/min
questions.hint: To estimate the filtered load of urea, we need to calculate this patient's glomerular filtration rate (GFR) using the dynamics of PAH. There is a nearly complete removal of all the PAH that flows through the kidney, so we can use PAH to estimate the effective renal plasma flow: eRPF = (UPAH * V)/PPAHwhere UPAH = urine PAH concentration, V = urine flow rate, and PPAH = plasma PAH concentration. We can then use the relationship between filtration fraction (FF) and eRPF to calculate the GFR (FF=GFR/eRPF) to obtain our estimate for the filtered load of urea.

questions.text:
A healthy 32-year-old woman enrolls in a study investigating kidney function. Her renal plasma flow (RPF) is 600 mL/min. She is administered an intravenous substance that does not undergo tubular reabsorption. The following sets of measurements are taken every 10 minutes:



Plasma concentration of substance
Excretion rate of substance



Set 1
0.1 mg/mL
60 mg/min


Set 2
0.15 mg/mL
90 mg/min


Set 3
0.2 mg/mL
104 mg/min


Set 4
0.25 mg/mL
110 mg/min


Set 5
0.3 mg/mL
116 mg/min



This patient was most likely administered which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystatin C is a protein produced in the human body and is freely filtered in the kidneys. Although it is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, it is not returned to the circulation, but undergoes immediate catabolization. It is not secreted in the tubular system. Therefore, the excretion rate of cystatin C is solely dependent on glomerular filtration. Since filtration of a solute is directly proportional to its plasma concentration, a linear rise in excretion rate would be expected. However, the substance administered to this patient shows a decreasing excretion slope above a specific excretion rate. Cystatin C is commonly used to estimate renal function, as its plasma concentration rises proportionally to a declining GFR.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucose is reabsorbed by the kidneys to a patient-specific threshold concentration (about 180 mg/dL), after which it is excreted; it is not secreted. A renal blood flow table illustrating glucose excretion would show 0 mg/min at low plasma concentrations, followed by an increase in the excretion rate proportional to rising plasma concentrations. This woman's set of measurement is therefore inconsistent with glucose administration. Moreover, according to the study description, she has been given a substance that does not undergo tubular reabsorption. Given the low blood concentrations of the injected substance initially measured in this patient (0.1 mg/mL), if the substance were glucose, it would mean that her blood glucose levels (10 mg/dL) would be so low as to be incompatible with life.
Image Description:

With a plasma glucose concentration less than 10 mmol/L (180mg/dL), all glucose is filtered from the glomerulus into the tubular lumen and then completely reabsorbed (through cotransport with sodium ions) in the proximal convoluted tubule through sodium-glucosecotransporters (SGLT2) such that the urine concentration of glucose is zero.

Above 10 mmol/L (180mg/dL) plasma glucose concentration, not all of the glucose can be reabsorbed by the proximal convoluted tubule. The maximum secretion rate (Tm 380mg/min) is reached above this blood glucose threshold, and some glucose will be excreted in the urine (glucosuria) at a concentration proportional to the plasma concentration of glucose.

C) CORRECT:

Para-aminohippurate (PAH) is a solute not naturally found in the human body that undergoes both free glomerular filtration (filtration fraction is normally ∼ 20%) and tubular secretion without being reabsorbed. This means that nearly 100% of all PAH that reaches the kidney is excreted, making it a popular choice for measuring renal plasma flow. Initially, PAH is excreted at an ideal rate that is dependent on plasma concentration and RPF (excretion rate = plasma concentration x RPF; set 1: 0.1 mg/mL x 600 mL/min = 60 mg/min). However, once the transporters for secretion are saturated (at about 80 mg/min), the excretion rate levels off (clearance decreases), as it is purely related to filtration (set 5: (0.3 mg/mL x 600 mL/min) x 0.2 = 36 mg/min; 80 mg/min + 36 mg/min = 116 mg/min). This patient's set of measurements is most consistent with administration of PAH.

Effective renal plasma flow can be estimated from the clearance of PAH with the following formula: eRPF = (urine concentration of PAH) x (urine flow rate/plasma concentration of PAH) = clearance of PAH.
Image Description:

The graph illustrates the ratio of the concentration of a given substance (tubular fluid; TF) in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) in proportion to its concentration in the plasma (P) along the length of the PCT (expressed as percent of distance). The substance inulin is neither secreted nor absorbed, and the concentration of TF:P increases as water is reabsorbed from the PCT.

D) INCORRECT:

Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubular system. Since filtration of a solute is directly proportional to its plasma concentration, a linear rise in excretion rate would be expected. However, the substance administered to this patient has a decreasing excretion slope above a specific excretion rate. Inulin can be used to calculate GFR, as the amount of it excreted in urine is equivalent to the amount filtered by the kidneys.
Image Description:

The relationship between plasma concentration of inulin and urine concentration is linear: Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubular system. The amount of inulin in the urine represents the amount that is filtered by the kidneys.

E) INCORRECT:

Iohexol is an IV or oral contrast dye commonly used in CT scans. It is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubular system. Since filtration of a solute is directly proportional to its plasma concentration, a linear rise in excretion rate would be expected. However, the substance administered to this patient has a decreasing excretion slope above a specific excretion rate. Iohexol can be used to calculate GFR because the amount of it excreted in urine is equivalent to the amount filtered by the kidneys.
questions.hint: The rate of excretion of a solute is equal to the sum of its filtration rate plus its secretion rate minus its reabsorption rate. Filtration of a solute is directly proportional to its plasma concentration, whereas secretion of a solute often reaches a transport maximum when the transporters are saturated. According to the changes in excretion rate seen in this set of measurements, a substance that undergoes both free filtration and secretion was administered.

questions.text: A group of investigators is studying glomerular dynamics in a human volunteer. At the beginning of the experiment, the subject's glomerular filtration rate (GFR) was 100 mL/min/1.73 m2, and their renal plasma flow (RPF) was 588 mL/min. After the administration of a drug, their RPF is 540 mL/min, and their filtration fraction (FF) is 0.2. The volunteer was most likely started on a drug that has which of the following effects?

choices.text: Inhibition of the renal Na-K-Cl cotransporter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Relaxation of urinary smooth muscle would occur in the setting of anticholinergic therapy, which is associated with urinary retention and potential subsequent postrenal AKI. In these rare cases, the RPF would remain unchanged, whereas GFR and FF would decrease. This patient has not described any complications with urinary retention. Moreover, her FF is increased, not decreased.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of the renal Na-K-Cl cotransporter occurs when loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) are administered. GFR and RPF generally remain unaffected unless hypovolemia ensues, which would lead to a compensatory response by the kidneys to maintain renal blood flow. This rare case would manifest with an increased FF due to a stronger decline in RPF than in GFR. Even though this patient's lab values reflect these changes, she does not exhibit any signs of hypovolemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of vasopressin can be seen in patients with extended lithium use, which is associated with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. These patients would present with free water loss and hypernatremia, but renal flow and filtration parameters would remain unchanged.

D) INCORRECT:

Constriction of the afferent arteriole would cause a decline in RPF and GFR, while the FF would remain unchanged, which is inconsistent with this patient's findings.

E) CORRECT:

Constriction of the efferent arteriole increases hydrostatic pressure within the glomerulus, which increases the GFR and reduces the RPF, thus resulting in an increased filtration fraction. This mechanism explains why this patient's FF increased while her RPF decreased. See “Changes in glomerular dynamics” table.

A decline in GFR is commonly seen in patients who are started on ACE inhibitors, which prevent constriction of the efferent arteriole by decreasing angiotensin II levels. Therefore, patients with prerenal failure should not be given ACEIs, as they would compromise the physiological response of the kidneys in striving to maintain adequate GFR.
questions.hint: FF = GFR/RPF, where FF = filtration fraction, GFR = glomerular filtration rate, and RPF = renal plasma flow. This patient's FF 1 month ago was 0.17 (100/588), meaning she was given a medication that decreased her RPF and increased her FF.

questions.text:
A laboratory technician processes basic metabolic panels for two patients. Patient A is 18 years old and patient B is 83 years old. Neither patient takes any medications regularly. Serum laboratory studies show:



Patient A
Patient B



Na+ (mEq/L)
140
141


K+ (mEq/L)
3.9
4.4


Cl- (mEq/L)
103
105


HCO3- (mEq/L)
25
21


BUN (mg/dL)
15
12


Cr (mg/dL)
0.8
1.2


Glucose (mg/dL)
105
98



Which of the following most likely accounts for the higher creatinine levels seen in patient B?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Low bone mineral density is likely given patient B's age. However, kidney function would be unaffected by osteoporosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is characterized by insulin resistance, can lead to chronic kidney disease and elevated creatinine. However, patient B's normal serum glucose makes insulin resistance an unlikely cause of her creatinine elevation.

C) CORRECT:

With age, GFR declines due to a decrease in renal parenchyma and renal blood flow, resulting in decreased clearance of serum creatinine in the kidneys and a subsequent increase in serum creatinine levels, as seen in this 83-year-old patient. The other laboratory values are within normal range for both patients. Age-related changes in serum creatinine must be taken into consideration when interpreting renal function monitoring results.

As serum creatinine is a product of muscle breakdown, lower muscle mass, which is common in older individuals due to frailty or chronic conditions, can result in decreased serum creatinine levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Volume depletion can cause dehydration or, if severe enough, acute kidney injury, which would result in an increase of serum creatinine as well as the concentration of other electrolytes, especially sodium and BUN. Patient B's normal electrolytes and normal BUN/Cr ratio, however, make a different etiology more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

A high salt diet can exacerbate hypertension, which can lead to chronic kidney disease manifesting with increased serum creatinine levels. However, a high salt diet alone would not directly affect the creatinine and patient B's lack of any medication use argues against chronic essential hypertension as an etiology of the increased creatinine.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine is a product of muscle breakdown and is expected to be lower in individuals with a lower BMI. A low BMI would not explain the elevation of creatinine seen in patient B.
questions.hint: Serum creatinine levels are an indirect measure of glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and thus renal function.

questions.text: An investigator is attempting to assess the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of a healthy adult volunteer. The volunteer's inulin clearance is evaluated under continuous inulin infusion and urine collection and compared to the creatinine clearance. It is found that the estimated GFR based on the volunteer's creatinine clearance is 129 mL/min and the estimated GFR calculated using the inulin clearance is 122 mL/min. Which of the following is the best explanation for the difference in these measurements?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The glomerular filtration barrier limits the passing of some substances into the Bowman capsule, which decreases their concentration in urine. However, creatinine clearance is not affected by the glomerular filtration barrier, as creatinine is freely filtered.

B) INCORRECT:

Passive reabsorption of a substance in the tubular system decreases its concentration in urine, which may cause the clearance to be underestimated. However, inulin clearance is not affected by this process.

C) INCORRECT:

Active secretion of a substance into the renal tubules increases its urine concentration and may cause the clearance to be overestimated. However, inulin is not actively secreted in the tubular system. Additionally, the GFR calculated from inulin clearance is lower than the GFR calculated from creatinine clearance in this experiment.

D) INCORRECT:

The glomerular filtration barrier limits the passing of some substances into the Bowman capsule, which decreases their concentration in urine. However, inulin clearance is not affected by the glomerular filtration barrier, as inulin is freely filtered.

E) INCORRECT:

Reabsorption of a substance from the renal tubules decreases its renal clearance. Although small amounts of creatinine can be reabsorbed in the renal tubules, this is predominantly seen in newborns. The amount of creatinine absorption in adults is minimal and the effect is offset by a more pronounced process.

F) CORRECT:

In addition to being freely filtered from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman capsule, small amounts of creatinine are actively secreted into the proximal tubules. This leads to an overestimation of the creatinine clearance by 10–20% and a resulting overestimation of the GFR. Inulin, on the other hand, is also freely filtered but is neither secreted nor reabsorbed. Therefore, the amount of inulin in the urine correlates linearly with the amount of filtered plasma and inulin clearance actually reflects the GFR.

Care should be taken when interpreting the creatinine clearance because creatinine serum levels depend on muscle mass and age of a patient. This results in higher creatinine clearance in young and active patients and lower creatinine clearance in old patients.
Image Description:

Clearance describes the assumed plasma volume that has been cleared by a substance within a certain period. It is a sensitive indicator for the assessment of kidney function.
questions.hint: GFR calculated using creatinine clearance is usually slightly higher than the actual GFR because of a process that occurs in the proximal tubule.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of a 2-day history of profound fatigue and generalized weakness. One week ago, she increased her basal insulin dose because of inadequate control of her glucose concentrations. Neurologic examination shows hyporeflexia. An ECG shows T-wave flattening and diffuse ST-segment depression. Which of the following changes are most likely to occur in this patient's kidneys?

choices.text: Increased activity of H+/K+ antiporter in α-intercalated cells
Decreased activity of epithelial Na+ channels in principal cells
Decreased activity of Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter in the loop of Henle
Decreased activity of Na+/H+ antiporter in the proximal convoluted tubule
Increased activity of luminal K+ channels in principal cells

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Increased H+/K+ activity in the α-intercalated cells of the collecting tubule occurs in response to hypokalemia. H+/K+ ATPase uses the energy derived from ATP hydrolysis to excrete hydrogen ions and reabsorb potassium ions. The kidney, therefore, enhances both collecting duct hydrogen ion secretion and potassium ion absorption to counteract low serum potassium.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased activity of epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC) in principal cells is expected in patients taking potassium-sparing diuretics such as amiloride and triamterene. This patient, however, has hypokalemia and no history of potassium-sparing diuretics use. Aldosterone increases the number and activity of ENaC channels in the collecting duct. In patients with insulin-induced hypokalemia, the activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system is increased (most often as a result of concomitant hypovolemia). Consequently, there is an increase rather than a decrease in the activity of the ENaC to increase reabsorption of Na+ and H20.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased activity of the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransport system of the loop of Henle is expected in patients using loop diuretics. This process may lead to hypokalemia. However, this patient has no history of diuretic use and the aforementioned decrease is unlikely to be seen in a patient with insulin-induced hypokalemia.

D) INCORRECT:

The activity of the Na+/H+ antiporter in the proximal convoluted tubule is upregulated by angiotensin II. In patients with insulin-induced hypokalemia, the activity of renin and angiotensin II is increased (most often as a result of concomitant hypovolemia). Consequently, there is an increase rather than a decrease in the activity of the Na+/H+ transporter on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule cell to increase reabsorption of Na+, H2O, and HCO3-.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased activity of luminal K+ channels in principal cells is observed in patients with hyperkalemia. H+/K+ ATPase on the basolateral side of the principal cell actively transports potassium from the blood into the cell, whereas K+ channels on the luminal side of the principal cells are responsible for secreting potassium into the urine. This is not an expected change in patients with insulin-induced hypokalemia.
questions.hint: The patient's fatigue, weakness, hyporeflexia, and ECG findings of T-wave flattening are characteristic of hypokalemia. Insulin can cause hypokalemia by promoting transport of potassium from the bloodstream into cells.
